awd_titl_txt: Identifying & Implementing Evidence-Based Online Tutoring Practices: Online Practices for Tutoring In Mathematics Using Meaningful Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the national need to provide support systems that enhance undergraduate STEM learning.  It will do so by investigating best practices for online tutoring in college mathematics.  Face-to-face tutoring in mathematics is known to correlate with positive learning outcomes including higher course grades, greater persistence, and improved retention. Providing quality online tutoring experiences also benefits for tutors by helping them learn valuable skills such as organization, time management, teamwork, problem-solving, leadership, and technical communication.  The COVID-19 pandemic forced many university-based tutoring services to either stop offering help to students or move online.  Many chose to move online.  However, the effective implementation of online mathematics tutoring is not yet well understood.  Such understanding is important because online mathematics tutoring could benefit students long after the current pandemic has dissipated. Preliminary observations have shown that online mathematics tutoring sessions typically serve as a homework service: tutors solve problems brought to them by students and the students watch and copy down the solutions rather than actively participating. This study aims to make the online tutoring experience more like the in-person experience by discovering ways to ensure students are active participants in tutoring sessions. Through continued observation of online tutor-student interactions, the project will identify tutor behaviors that encourage greater student participation in online tutoring sessions.  The project will then design training materials to promote the most effective behaviors in tutors.  These training materials will be freely distributed to the mathematics education community through workshops, conference presentations, and online resources.  

This project’s online tutoring model will be tested and refined at West Virginia University and the University of Oklahoma, two large universities that server large populations of students.  The project will identify tutor practices that promote student-centered online tutoring interactions and generate training materials to optimize the frequency of such interactions in online tutoring sessions. Recorded online tutoring sessions will be analyzed using inductive and deductive thematic analysis to identify tutor behaviors that promote student-centered tutoring interactions.  Pen and tablet technologies will be utilized and compared to online sessions without such tools to study specific impacts on tutor practices and student engagement.  Through multiple cycles of observation and implementation, a set of empirically tested training materials will be developed, including a Tutoring Manual for tutors and a Training Guide for tutoring center leaders/faculty. The Training Manual for tutors will contain resources such as technology suggestions (e.g., best collaborative whiteboard app; how to use your phone as a document camera; apps to scan written work to pdf), articles to read, and how to be an effective virtual coach. The Training Guide for faculty will provide resources such as how to host a one-day training before the semester starts, how to support tutors during the semester, and how to evaluate online tutoring offerings. This project is funded through the NSF IUSE:EHR program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).  The IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The OPTIMUM Interactions project was collaboratively conducted across three institutions: University of Nebraska at Omaha, West Virginia University, and University of Oklahoma. The goals of the project were to identify practices that promote student-centered online mathematics tutoring practices and create materials to support the training of online tutors. We created two training manuals: one for people who train tutors and one for tutors. These training materials were shared in three workshops hosted by the PIs and are available through an online repository (Google Drive folder). Training materials include six video case studies (simulated online tutoring sessions) that workshop participants were excited to use in their training sessions; two have been viewed over one hundred times. The project has yielded five conference proceedings papers/presentations, one book chapter, and three conference poster presentations.

Online tutoring necessitates tutors have access to technology to facilitate communication. Tutors in this project received a tablet and training on how to use the tablet to promote better communication in the online tutoring environment. Our research found that tutors made regular use of shared virtual whiteboard software that allowed both the tutor and their tutees to write in a collaborative online space. When a lack of appropriate technology prevented tutees from writing in these collaborative spaces, tutors employed the highly effective practice of acting as scribes and taking dictation from students as they explained their work. This provided a way for students to remain active participants in their tutoring sessions even when they did not have access to sophisticated technology. Further, many tutors became adept at using colors, arrows, and circles to supplant traditional hand gestures.

Our research found that the tutor-to-student ratio sometimes presented a challenge for tutors in the online space. Video conferencing software only allows for one conversation taking place at a time; in situations where more than one tutee requested help, this often meant that one or more students had to wait for an extended period of time while the tutor helped someone else. However, our work found that tutors who had extensive in-person tutoring experience were much more capable of balancing multiple tutees at once by giving a tutee a small amount of direction followed by a task for them to try on their own while they worked with someone else.

We found that a tutor’s ability to build rapport with tutees had a strong impact on the quality of an online tutoring session. This was so important that tutees were sometimes willing to wait up to an hour or more for help from an experienced tutor with whom they had built a relationship. Tutees also stayed online to work with a tutor for longer periods of time when they had positive interpersonal interactions during their sessions. Important aspects of positive interpersonal interactions included the tutor using the tutee’s name, the tutor’s attention to the tutee’s motivation for attending tutoring (e.g., whether the tutee was seeking conceptual understanding or simply to complete a homework assignment), the tutor responding supportively to the tutee’s successes as well as their failures, and the tutor’s willingness to discuss topics unrelated to mathematics (e.g., the tutee’s plans for the weekend or how their other classes were going).

During the first year of the project, online tutoring was in high demand, at least in part due to the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic. Over time, visits to online tutors decreased. However, many institutions have maintained some form of online tutoring, particularly to serve students who need help during evening hours. Additionally, since faculty and students have returned to campus, many courses continue to be taught online, both synchronously and asynchronously, and many faculty have elected to hold at least some of their office hours online via video conferencing software. Our research provides insights into the best ways to serve learners in these online settings. Although some degree of technology is necessary to engage with online tutoring, our results suggest means by which tutors and faculty in online spaces can promote student-centered learning experiences with minimal equipment required by the student. Tutors who were trained for the online tutoring environment gained valuable skills that will potentially transfer to their future careers, e.g., developing working relationships and how to adapt and improvise when technology does not work as expected.
